page.title: 04ECOLOGY OF THE TADLEY AREA 2
page.content: Ancient woodlands are sites known to have had trees on them for at least 300 years, they are rich in wildlife and recently both Berkshire and Hampshire County Councils have been compiling Inventories. Among the ancient woodlands of the Tadley area are Inwood Copse, Chaplin's Wood, Redlands Wood and Wasing Wood which is notified by the Nature Conservancy Council as an SSSI (Site of Special Scientific Interest) because of its importance for dragonflies. Ashford Hill Meadows are superb examples of traditionally managed hay and grazing meadows, now very rare and extremely rich in plant species, surrounded by ancient woodlands rich in insect life. Because of their importance to nature conservation they are shortly to be declared as a National Nature Reserve by the Nature Conservancy Council.
